description: Borrowed from Latin commūnicātus, perfect passive participle of commūnicō (“share, impart; make common”), from commūnis (“common”). Doublet of commune.

verbs.description: communicate (third-person singular simple present communicates, present participle communicating, simple past and past participle communicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impart or transmit (information or knowledge) to someone; to make known, to tell. [from 16th c.]
examples: It is vital that I communicate this information to you.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impart or transmit (an intangible quantity, substance); to give a share of. [from 16th c.]
examples: to communicate motion by means of a crank

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pass on (a disease) to another person, animal etc. [from 17th c.]
examples: The disease was mainly communicated via rats and other vermin.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To share (in); to have in common, to partake of. [16th–19th c.]
examples: We shall now consider those functions of intelligence which man communicates with the higher beasts.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Christianity) To receive the bread and wine at a celebration of the Eucharist; to take part in Holy Communion. [from 16th c.]
examples: It seems that now [the Devil] was driving Alison hard. She had been remiss of late — fewer souls sent to hell, less zeal in quenching the Spirit, and, above all, the crowning offense that her bairn had communicated in Christ's kirk.

entries.meaning: (transitive, Christianity) To administer the Holy Communion to (someone). [from 16th c.]
(intransitive) To express or convey ideas, either through verbal or nonverbal means; to have intercourse, to exchange information. [from 16th c.]
examples: Many deaf people communicate with sign language.
I feel I hardly know him; I just wish he'd communicate with me a little more.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be connected with (another room, vessel etc.) by means of an opening or channel. [from 16th c.]
examples: The living room communicates with the back garden by these French windows.
